study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of micelle silymarin (MS) supplementation on the performance, egg quality, water loss, and blood profile of laying hens.
results_summary: MS supplementation linearly improved Haugh units, egg weight, eggshell strength, albumen height, and eggshell thickness while reducing egg yolk color and water loss. It also decreased aspartate aminotransferase and cholesterol levels without affecting hens' growth performance.
population_specificity: 288 Hy-Line brown laying hens, 28 weeks old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how silymarin and a polyherbal extract interact with gut microbiota to ameliorate non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in mice.
results_summary: Silymarin and the polyherbal extract significantly improved liver steatosis and function, increased beneficial probiotics (Akkermansia, Blautia), and suppressed harmful bacteria (Clostridium), linked to changes in bile acids. Fecal microbiome transplantation confirmed these microbiota alterations were responsible for NAFLD improvement.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with HFD-induced NAFLD.
effective_dosage: Medium and high doses of Silybum marianum extract (containing silymarin) or polyherbal extract (containing silymarin, salvianolic acids B, and puerarin); exact amounts not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective and therapeutic effects of silymarin and dexmedetomidine on lung and kidney tissue in rats with sepsis induced by the cecal ligation and puncture method.
results_summary: Silymarin administration increased kidney damage compared to the sepsis-only group, while dexmedetomidine reduced kidney damage. Co-administration of both partially ameliorated injury but was less effective than dexmedetomidine alone.
population_specificity: Rats with sepsis induced by cecal ligation and puncture.
study_duration: Single dose administered 1 hour before or after sepsis induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the kidney protective effects of silymarin against thioacetamide-induced renal fibrosis in rats, comparing its efficacy to exosomes of mesenchymal stem cells.
results_summary: Silymarin significantly reversed thioacetamide-induced increases in serum urea, creatinine, TGF-β receptor expression, collagen I, CTGF proteins, and SMAD proteins, though exosomes showed superior efficacy in restoring some markers to near-control levels.
population_specificity: Female rats with thioacetamide-induced renal fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and characterize silymarin-loaded niosomes as a drug delivery system, evaluating their stability, release behavior, and therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study found that silymarin-loaded niosomes exhibited high encapsulation efficiency (91%), sustained release, improved antimicrobial and cytotoxic effects, and favorable safety profiles in vivo compared to bulk silymarin.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo evaluations, but no human subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Silymarin in regulating energy metabolism, attenuating liver damage, and improving liver histology in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Silymarin significantly reduced levels of TC, TG, LDL-C, FI, HOMA-IR, ALT, AST, fatty liver index, and fatty liver score while increasing HDL-C. It also improved hepatic steatosis in liver histology.
population_specificity: 2,375 patients with NAFLD across 26 randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding Silymarin to GelMA bioink could protect bioprinted liver tissue from oxidative stress and drug-induced hepatotoxicity.
results_summary: Silymarin improved albumin synthesis and protected liver tissue from CCl4-induced damage, reducing TNF-α and enhancing SOD expression in HepG2 cells.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (liver cancer cell line) in a bioprinted liver construct.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of silymarin antioxidant serum, both alone and in combination with prescription acne treatments, on improving facial appearance in blemish-prone skin.
results_summary: Silymarin reduced inflammatory lesions by 45% and noninflammatory lesions by 43% in one study, while another study showed reductions in facial erythema (60%), dryness (49%), and scaling (67%) when used alongside prescription acne therapy. It also decreased oiliness by 16% and improved markers of skin aging.
population_specificity: Blemish-prone individuals in Brazil (56 subjects) and acne patients on prescription medications in the US/Germany (40 subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining silymarin with antiviral therapy (AVT) could reduce mortality and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) incidence in patients with HBV-related liver cirrhosis (HBV-LC).
results_summary: The study found that silymarin combined with AVT significantly improved mortality outcomes and comorbidity indices but did not affect HCC occurrence. The case cohort showed better one-year and two-year survival rates compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 8447 HBV-LC patients (after matching, 319 in each cohort) undergoing AVT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Silymarin on biochemical and transaminase levels in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) or metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).
results_summary: Silymarin significantly reduced ALT, AST, and TG levels while improving HDL. No significant effects were observed for GGT, TC, LDL, HOMA-IR, or BMI, though one study noted fibrosis improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with NAFLD/MASLD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether silymarin could mitigate the negative effects of aflatoxin B1 on rat body weight and reproductive organs.
results_summary: Silymarin improved growth, reproductive organ health, and gene expression (TNF-α, LHR, StAR) while restoring normal testicular architecture in rats exposed to aflatoxin B1. It also counteracted the toxin's negative effects on body weight and testosterone levels.
population_specificity: Mature male Wistar white rats (average weight 83.67 ± 0.21 g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of micelle silymarin (MS) supplementation on productive performance, egg quality, and blood biochemical parameters in laying hens.
results_summary: MS supplementation linearly improved egg production percentage, egg weight, feed conversion ratio, feed intake, eggshell thickness, and eggshell strength, while reducing cholesterol levels in hens. Eggshell color, Haugh unit, and albumin height showed no significant differences, but yolk color improved at higher MS levels.
population_specificity: 384 Hy-Line brown laying hens (28-week-old).
effective_dosage: 0%, 0.02%, 0.04%, and 0.06% of MS added to the basal diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether silymarin alone could improve insulin resistance (IR) in non-diabetic, insulin-resistant women with obesity.
results_summary: Silymarin significantly reduced fasting plasma glucose and HOMA-IR levels after 12 weeks, suggesting potential benefits for IR. Other metabolic parameters (e.g., cholesterol, triglycerides) showed non-significant improvements.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic, insulin-resistant women with type 1 or type 2 obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a novel hydrogel containing silymarin (SM) and levofloxacin (LEV) to accelerate third-degree burn wound healing.
results_summary: The hydrogel significantly accelerated wound closure (98.1% vs. 75.1% in controls) by day 21, with histopathological analysis showing reduced inflammation, likely due to the antioxidant and antibiotic properties of silymarin and levofloxacin.
population_specificity: Third-degree burn wound patients (animal or human model not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of Silymarin consumption on inflammation and oxidative stress factors through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Silymarin significantly reduced CRP, MDA, and IL-6 levels, indicating anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects, but had no significant impact on IL-10, TAC, or GSH. A non-linear relationship was observed between intervention duration and MDA changes.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes and thalassemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of a phytogenic feed additive containing silymarin and silymarin alone on broilers' productive performance and liver function, with and without induced liver damage.
results_summary: The study found that the phytogenic feed additive (CA-PFA) improved body weight gain and feed conversion ratio in broilers, both with and without induced liver damage, compared to a basal diet and standard silymarin. Silymarin alone was used as a reference due to its known hepatoprotective properties, but the abstract does not detail its standalone efficacy.
population_specificity: One-day-old male broilers (Cobb Vantress 500).
effective_dosage: 70 mg/kg of silymarin (provided via CA-PFA at 500 mg/kg feed or silymarin at 250 mg/kg feed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of silymarin on oxidative stress biomarkers, inflammation, and disease severity in Alzheimer's patients.
results_summary: Silymarin significantly reduced catalase and MDA serum levels and notably increased MMSE scores, indicating reduced oxidative stress and improved cognitive function in Alzheimer's patients.
population_specificity: 33 patients with Alzheimer's disease confirmed by DSM-5 criteria and brain imaging.
effective_dosage: Three 250 mg silymarin capsules daily (each containing 150 mg silymarin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of silymarin and the MAPK pathway in regulating the proliferation and invasion of non-small cell lung cancer cells.
results_summary: Silymarin inhibited the proliferation and invasion of non-small cell lung cancer cells, with higher concentrations showing more pronounced effects. It reduced the expression of MMP-2, MMP-9, p-p38, and p-JNK, suggesting inhibition of the MAPK pathway.
population_specificity: Non-small cell lung cancer cells in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate silymarin's hepatoprotective, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antifibrotic properties for managing chronic liver diseases.
results_summary: Silymarin demonstrated potential as an efficacious and tolerable herbal product for liver disease management, showing hepatoprotective and therapeutic effects. The study highlights its promise but notes no approved drug therapy currently exists for these conditions.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic liver diseases, including non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, metabolic-associated fatty liver disease, drug-induced liver injury, and alcoholic liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of silymarin compared to rosuvastatin and placebo on neuro-metabolites, serum levels of LRP1 and Aβ1-42 proteins, oxidative stress enzymes, lipid profiles, and cognitive tests in mild Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients.
results_summary: Silymarin significantly increased LRP1 and Aβ1-42 levels, improved NAA/mI ratios, and showed correlations with lipid profiles and neurometabolites, suggesting potential benefits in AD pathology.
population_specificity: Iranian patients with mild Alzheimer's disease (n=12 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of oral silymarin on hepatic function in pediatric patients with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
results_summary: Silymarin intake resulted in a slight but significant decrease in ALT, AST, GGT, and bilirubin levels, but had no effect on ALP, albumin, and cholesterol. The study suggests silymarin improves liver function in pediatric ALL patients.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (over 5 years of age) with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
effective_dosage: 70 mg oral capsules twice daily or syrup (5 ml containing 50 mg silymarin) three times a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of co-treatment with Silymarin (SLM) and Cisplatin (Cis) on A2780 human ovarian cancer cell lines, focusing on viability, migration, colony formation, apoptosis, and miRNA expression.
results_summary: SLM significantly reduced A2780 cell proliferation in a concentration- and time-dependent manner. Combined SLM and Cis treatment was more effective than either alone in reducing viability, suppressing migration, inhibiting colony formation, promoting apoptosis, and altering miR-155 and miR-27a expression.
population_specificity: A2780 human ovarian cancer cell lines

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer effects of niosomal encapsulated silymarin, alone and in combination with quercetin, on diethylnitrosamine-induced hepatocellular carcinoma in rats.
results_summary: The combination of niosomal encapsulated silymarin and quercetin (50 mg/kg) showed significant restoration of biomarkers (alpha-fetoprotein, carcinoembryonic antigen) and antioxidants (superoxide dismutase, nitric oxide), along with improved liver architecture in histopathological examination.
population_specificity: Male rats with diethylnitrosamine-induced hepatocellular carcinoma.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg of niosomal encapsulated silymarin (alone or in combination with quercetin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiproliferative and antitelomerase effects of silymarin on human colorectal cancer and hepatocyte carcinoma cells.
results_summary: Silymarin inhibited cell proliferation and telomerase activity in all tested cancer cells, with IC50 values ranging from 19–56.3 µg/mL. It also downregulated human telomerase reverse transcriptase expression but did not affect promoter methylation.
population_specificity: Human colorectal cancer and HepG2 hepatocyte carcinoma cell lines.
effective_dosage: 10, 30, and 60 µg/mL for 48 h; IC50 concentrations (19–56.3 µg/mL) for 30 min.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve Silymarin's solubility and therapeutic activity by developing solid dispersions using different carriers and methods, and to evaluate its anti-cancer effects.
results_summary: The study found that ternary solid dispersions significantly enhanced Silymarin's solubility and drug release, with F9 showing the greatest improvement. The cell viability assay demonstrated enhanced anti-cancer activity compared to free Silymarin.
population_specificity: Lung cancer cell line (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining iron with Silymarin nanoliposomes (SLM Lip) could shift its antioxidant properties to prooxidant activity, enhancing cytotoxicity against cancer cells and improving therapeutic outcomes in a breast cancer model.
results_summary: The study found that Fe + SLM Lip induced greater toxicity in 4T1 breast cancer cells compared to SLM Lip alone, reduced catalase activity time-dependently, and demonstrated superior therapeutic efficacy in a mouse breast cancer model, leading to longer survival and significant tumor necrosis without major organ damage.
population_specificity: Mice bearing 4T1 breast cancer tumors.
interactions: Iron sucrose was noted to enhance the prooxidant and cytotoxic effects of SLM Lip.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of topical silymarin cream compared to salicylic acid peels for treating mild to moderate acne vulgaris.
results_summary: Silymarin cream showed comparable efficacy to salicylic acid peels in reducing acne severity, with no reported side effects, while hyperpigmentation occurred in some cases with salicylic acid.
population_specificity: 30 patients with mild to moderate acne vulgaris.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Silymarin could protect against testicular ischemia-reperfusion (I/R) injury in rats by evaluating histopathological and biochemical parameters.
results_summary: Silymarin significantly improved total antioxidant status (TAS) and reduced total oxidant status (TOS), as well as mitigated testicular damage (Johnson score) and inflammation/apoptosis markers (Bax and Annexin V immunostaining) compared to the untreated I/R group. No significant differences were found in MDA, MPO, or GSH levels.
population_specificity: Male Wistar albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective efficacy of testosterone and silymarin (TNSN) against oxidative stress and inflammation in the liver of rats with type 2 diabetes and obesity (DMOB).
results_summary: The study found that TNSN treatment effectively normalized abnormal levels of body mass, serum markers, glucose, HbA1c, lipid profiles, antioxidants, inflammatory cytokines, and gene expression pathways in DMOB rats, demonstrating significant protective effects against liver abnormalities.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with induced type 2 diabetes and obesity (DMOB).
study_duration: 20 weeks (with STZ injection on the 9th week)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether silymarin (SIL) could mitigate liver injury induced by ethanol and LPS in mice, focusing on antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: Silymarin (200 mg/kg) did not prevent increased liver enzyme levels, restore glutathione or malonaldehyde levels, or improve antioxidant enzyme activity. It also failed to reduce microsteatosis or inflammatory markers (IL-6, IL-10) compared to NAC.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to ethanol and LPS-induced liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of silymarin against 3-NP-induced neurotoxicity in mice, focusing on behavioral, oxidative, and inflammatory outcomes.
results_summary: Silymarin significantly attenuated 3-NP-induced behavioral deficits, oxidative stress, and neuroinflammation in both pretreatment and treatment protocols, suggesting its neuroprotective potential via mitigation of oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Six-week-old male mice
study_duration: 2 weeks pretreatment or 4 weeks post-3-NP administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of silymarin against cadmium-induced oxidative stress and liver damage in rats, as well as its ability to restore normal enzyme activities.
results_summary: Silymarin restored antioxidant enzyme activities, reduced oxidative stress markers, and normalized drug-metabolizing enzyme levels in cadmium-exposed rats. It also mitigated liver damage, showing comparable efficacy to garlic extract and synergistic effects when combined.
population_specificity: Male rats exposed to cadmium chloride.
effective_dosage: 25 mg/kg, administered orally for 28 consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of silymarin on Nile tilapia against oxytetracycline-induced immunosuppression and Aeromonas hydrophila infection.
results_summary: Silymarin improved blood parameters, reduced mortality by 37%, enhanced antioxidative enzyme levels, and modulated immune responses in Nile tilapia infected with A. hydrophila.
population_specificity: Nile tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of silymarin against hepatotoxic damage induced by diazinon in rainbow trout.
results_summary: Silymarin mitigated oxidative stress and restored enzyme activities in fish exposed to diazinon, maintaining normal levels of glucose, triglycerides, cholesterol, and proteins. However, it had limited effectiveness on creatine phosphokinase, glutathione reductase, and ammonia excretion.
population_specificity: Rainbow trout

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of silymarin supplementation on blood lipids in adults, particularly its impact on total cholesterol, LDL, HDL, and triglycerides.
results_summary: Silymarin supplementation in combination with other treatments reduced total cholesterol and LDL, increased HDL, and significantly lowered triglycerides compared to controls.
population_specificity: Adults with hyperlipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether silymarin supplementation could reduce toxicities, particularly diarrhea, in metastatic colorectal cancer patients undergoing irinotecan-based chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that the silymarin group experienced fewer adverse events of diarrhea (5.7% vs. 14.6%) compared to the control group, suggesting a potential benefit in reducing irinotecan-induced toxicity.
population_specificity: Metastatic colorectal cancer patients receiving first-line FOLFIRI plus bevacizumab.
effective_dosage: 150 mg three times daily for 7 days per treatment cycle.
study_duration: 7 days per treatment cycle (total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of silymarin supplementation on metabolic status and oxidative stress in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) through a meta-analysis.
results_summary: Silymarin supplementation reduced fasting blood sugar, hemoglobin A1C, insulin, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and malondialdehyde while increasing high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels, but had no significant effect on total cholesterol or triglycerides.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential radiosensitization effects of silymarin/silibinin during cancer radiation exposure/radiotherapy.
results_summary: Silymarin/silibinin synergistically increased ionizing radiation-induced cytotoxicity in cancer cells, reduced tumor volume, weight, and growth in mice, and enhanced biochemical and histopathological changes in tumoral cells/tissues.
population_specificity: Cancer cells and tumor-bearing mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of silymarin supplementation on glycemic indices and serum lipid profile in type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) patients.
results_summary: Silymarin supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood sugar, serum insulin, insulin resistance, triglycerides, and improved HDL cholesterol levels in T2DM patients compared to placebo. It also lowered total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol levels from baseline.
population_specificity: 40 T2DM patients (20 male, 20 female), aged 25-50 years, on stable medication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Silymarin and/or vitamin E on oxidative stress markers and hemoglobin levels in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The combination of Silymarin and vitamin E reduced malondialdehyde (MDA) levels, increased red blood cell glutathione peroxidase (GPX) levels, and improved hemoglobin levels compared to controls. The effects were more pronounced with the combination therapy than with either supplement alone.
population_specificity: Patients on hemodialysis with end-stage renal disease.
effective_dosage: Silymarin 140 mg 3 times daily; vitamin E 400 IU/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of an educational intervention on the implementation of skin-to-skin care (SSC) in the NICU, focusing on SSC time, frequency, and early adoption.
results_summary: The study found that after the educational intervention, the prevalence of infants receiving SSC within their first 24 hours, the number of daily SSC sessions, and the duration of each session increased, with effects lasting over 2 years.
population_specificity: Neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) infants and their parents.
study_duration: Effects were observed over 2 years post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess silymarin's role in reducing liver inflammation and oxidative stress induced by carbon tetrachloride (CCl4) in rats.
results_summary: Silymarin reduced liver inflammation by countering oxidative stress and lowering inflammatory cytokine production (NF-κB, TNF-α, IL-6, COX-2, TGF-β), as confirmed by histopathology.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (130 ± 10 g weight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between inpatient skin-to-skin care rates and neurodevelopmental outcomes at 12 months in very preterm infants.
results_summary: Higher rates of skin-to-skin care were positively associated with improved neurodevelopmental scores at 12 months, accounting for 6.2% unique variance after adjusting for confounders. A 20-minute daily increase in skin-to-skin care was linked to a 10-point improvement in neurodevelopmental outcomes.
population_specificity: Very preterm infants (<32 weeks gestational age at birth).
study_duration: Duration of hospital stay (specific length not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether implementing a dedicated neonatal assessment nurse (NAN) role could improve rates of immediate skin-to-skin care (SSC) and exclusive breastfeeding during the postpartum hospital stay.
results_summary: The study found that the NAN role significantly increased SSC rates (from 49% to 82% after vaginal birth and from 33% to 63% after cesarean birth) and exclusive breastfeeding rates at discharge (from 50% to 86%). Nurses demonstrated improved knowledge and met competency criteria for the new role.
population_specificity: Registered nurses and newborns in a tertiary care teaching hospital in the southeastern United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of immediate skin-to-skin care (SSC) versus swaddling in reducing pain response to intramuscular vitamin K injection in neonates.
results_summary: SSC significantly reduced pain scores (NIPS) at 2 minutes post-injection compared to swaddling, with fewer newborns in the SSC group showing high pain scores. SSC also lowered pain scores below baseline, while swaddling resulted in higher pain scores than baseline.
population_specificity: Healthy full-term newborns delivered vaginally.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was SSC or swaddling, not a dosage-based treatment).
study_duration: Immediate intervention at 30 minutes post-birth, with pain assessment up to 2 minutes post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility and acceptability of teaching mindfulness during Kangaroo Care (KC) for mothers of premature babies in the NICU and to assess its effects on maternal stress, anxiety, depression, and mindful awareness.
results_summary: The study found that mothers practicing mindfulness during KC (MKC) showed significant reductions in anxiety, depression, and stress, along with increased mindful awareness (curiosity and decentering). The intervention was deemed acceptable and feasible by most participants.
population_specificity: Mothers of premature babies admitted to the NICU with an expected stay of at least four weeks.
effective_dosage: Two mindfulness exercises practiced during KC (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early polyethylene bag use combined with skin-to-skin care reduces hypothermia in term-born infants compared to skin-to-skin care alone in resource-limited settings.
results_summary: The study found that skin-to-skin care with polyethylene bags significantly reduced moderate-severe hypothermia at 1 hour (34.6% vs. 47.4%) compared to skin-to-skin care alone, with no significant differences in severe hypothermia, hyperthermia, or adverse events between groups.
population_specificity: Term-born infants in a tertiary referral center in Lusaka, Zambia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved polyethylene bag use with skin-to-skin care).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the experiences of mothers using skin-to-skin care (SSC) for infants with neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS), including perceived barriers and benefits.
results_summary: SSC was described as beneficial for bonding and healing, though mothers reported challenges such as emotional stress and hospital-related barriers. Four key themes emerged, highlighting both the positive impact and difficulties of SSC for this population.
population_specificity: Postpartum mothers of infants with neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early skin-to-skin care (SSC) intervention (≤16 days of life) compared to later SSC (>16 days of life) increased the likelihood of extremely low birth weight (ELBW) infants receiving mother's own milk (MOM) at discharge.
results_summary: Early SSC intervention increased from 46% to 73% among ELBW infants during the study period, and frequency of SSC was associated with higher rates of MOM at discharge (p < .05). ELBW infants in the early SSC group received more MOM at discharge compared to those in the later SSC group.
population_specificity: Extremely low birth weight (ELBW) infants.
study_duration: Intervention timing was ≤16 days of life vs. >16 days of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of skin-to-skin care (SSC) on maternal stress (anxiety and cortisol levels) and attachment (attachment scores and oxytocin levels) before and after neonatal cardiac surgery.
results_summary: SSC significantly reduced maternal anxiety and salivary cortisol levels while increasing self-reported attachment scores, though no significant changes in oxytocin were observed.
population_specificity: Thirty mothers of infants hospitalized for neonatal cardiac surgery at a large children's hospital.
study_duration: Two time points (before and after surgery)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of combining music therapy with skin-to-skin care (SSC) on regional cerebral oxygenation (rSO2) and physiological stability in premature infants.
results_summary: The study found a modest but significant increase in rSO2 during SSC with music therapy and post-intervention phases, along with reduced variability in rSO2 and SpO2, suggesting short-term benefits. No significant changes were observed in heart rate, SpO2, or cFTOE.
population_specificity: Preterm infants in a tertiary neonatal intensive care unit.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of quiet SSC, 20 minutes of SSC with live maternal singing and guitar music, followed by another 30 minutes of quiet SSC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to increase the frequency of skin-to-skin care, parental holds, and parent touch events for infants in a cardiac and surgical neonatal intensive care unit, particularly when traditional SSC was not feasible.
results_summary: The study found an increased frequency of SSC and a variety of holds or alternative parent touch events post-intervention. Staff surveys supported the practice but identified persistent barriers.
population_specificity: Term and preterm infants in a cardiac and surgical neonatal intensive care unit.

study_goal: To determine the effect of skin-to-skin care on stress, pain, behavioral organization, and physiologic stability in infants with critical congenital heart disease before and after neonatal cardiac surgery.
results_summary: Skin-to-skin care significantly reduced pain scores and promoted calmer behavior states in infants at both preoperative and postoperative stages. It also improved physiologic stability (reduced heart and respiratory rates, increased systolic blood pressure) preoperatively, while cortisol levels remained stable during care but increased afterward, particularly in infants with higher baseline cortisol.
population_specificity: 30 infants admitted preoperatively for critical congenital heart disease in a cardiac ICU and step-down unit.
effective_dosage: 1 hour of skin-to-skin care with biological mothers once preoperatively (T1) and once postoperatively (T2).
study_duration: Two sessions (preoperative and postoperative), each lasting 1 hour.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand women's experiences, concerns, and expectations regarding skin-to-skin care during cesarean birth.
results_summary: The study found that women highly valued their skin-to-skin care experience post-cesarean birth, reinforcing the importance of advocating for and implementing this practice whenever possible. Themes highlighted the significance of the intervention in their overall birth experience.
population_specificity: Women who had skin-to-skin care post-cesarean birth within the last 10 years (N = 13).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acceptability of reducing light and noise levels during skin-to-skin care (SSC) in the NICU among nurses and whether it interfered with care delivery.
results_summary: Most nurses found reducing light and noise levels during SSC acceptable, reported no interference with care delivery, and approved of nine specific interventions for reducing these levels. The findings support further research via a full-scale RCT to evaluate the intervention's impact on preterm infants and mothers' well-being.
population_specificity: Neonatal nurses from a level III NICU and preterm infants/mothers undergoing SSC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, safety, and outcomes of immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin care (SSC) during cesarean surgery, focusing on maternal/newborn physiologic stability, stress, comfort, satisfaction, and exclusive breast milk feeding rates.
results_summary: Immediate SSC during cesarean surgery was feasible and safe, with no negative effects on maternal or newborn physiologic stability. Women who received SSC during surgery reported higher satisfaction and lower stress (measured by salivary cortisol), though exclusive breast milk feeding rates at discharge did not differ between groups.
population_specificity: Women undergoing medically uncomplicated cesarean surgery and their newborns (n=40 total, 20 per group).
effective_dosage: SSC began either immediately after birth (Group 1, average 0.89 minutes) or post-surgery (Group 2, average 46 minutes), lasting an average of 300 minutes and 126 minutes, respectively.
study_duration: SSC continued uninterrupted for approximately 5 hours in Group 1 and 2 hours in Group 2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether skin-to-skin care (SSC) improves short-term physiologic stress outcomes in premature infants in the NICU compared to incubator care.
results_summary: The study found that SSC improves short-term cardiorespiratory stress outcomes and strongly reduces cortisol while increasing oxytocin levels in preterm infants, though some mixed findings were noted. The evidence supports SSC as a beneficial intervention for stress reduction in the NICU.
population_specificity: Premature infants in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether skin-to-skin care reduces postpartum depression (PPD) among mothers of preterm or low birthweight infants.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a small but statistically significant reduction (1.04%) in standardized depression scores with skin-to-skin care compared to standard care, though clinical relevance was minimal and heterogeneity among studies was high.
population_specificity: Mothers of preterm or low birthweight infants in neonatal intensive care units (NICUs).
effective_dosage: Sessions ranged from 15 minutes to 1 hour, with frequency from thrice daily to thrice weekly.
study_duration: Intervention duration varied from one week to over two months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the physiologic stress mechanisms in NICU infants and how skin-to-skin care (SSC) mitigates these stress responses.
results_summary: SSC was found to be a safe and effective intervention for reducing stress in NICU infants and their parents, supported by current literature. Barriers and facilitators to its implementation were also reviewed.
population_specificity: Critically ill infants in the NICU and their parents.

study_goal: To investigate the feasibility and safety of skin-to-skin care after birth for moderately preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in body temperature or blood glucose levels between preterm infants receiving skin-to-skin care and those receiving conventional incubator treatment, suggesting skin-to-skin care may be feasible and safe.
population_specificity: Preterm infants born vaginally with gestational ages of 32 weeks/0 days to 34 weeks/6 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of prolonged skin-to-skin care (SSC) during blood glucose monitoring in late preterm and term infants at-risk for neonatal hypoglycemia.
results_summary: The study found that SSC significantly reduced hypoglycemia admissions to the neonatal intensive care unit (from 8.1% to 3.5%) and decreased intravenous dextrose bolus administration (from 5.9% to 2.1%). Exclusive breastfeeding rates increased but were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Late preterm and term infants at-risk for neonatal hypoglycemia.
effective_dosage: Prolonged SSC during blood glucose monitoring (12-24 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of skin-to-skin care (SSC) on procedural pain in neonates compared to no intervention, sucrose, or other analgesics, and to assess the safety and optimal administration methods of SSC.
results_summary: SSC was effective in reducing pain indicators such as heart rate and crying time, particularly during heel lance and intramuscular injection procedures. No adverse events were reported, and SSC was found to be safe for single painful procedures.
population_specificity: Term infants (≥37 weeks' postmenstrual age) and preterm infants (<37 weeks' postmenstrual age).
study_duration: Duration of SSC varied by study (specifics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness and clinical benefits of an intervention ("Getting It Right From the Start") designed to increase breastfeeding and kangaroo skin-to-skin care rates in neonatal units.
results_summary: The intervention demonstrated significant cost savings, with every £1 invested generating £4.00 to £13.82 in benefits, primarily from increased skin-to-skin care and breastfeeding. The greatest savings were linked to reductions in gastroenteritis and necrotising enterocolitis cases.
population_specificity: Neonatal units in two Neonatal Networks in the UK (18 units total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize and interpret qualitative findings on parental experiences of skin-to-skin care (SSC) for newborn infants.
results_summary: SSC was found to be both restorative and energy-draining for parents, with a supportive environment facilitating positive experiences. Positive experiences enhanced parental self-esteem and readiness to assume full responsibility for their child.
population_specificity: 401 mothers and 94 fathers from 9 countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the acceptance and barriers to skin-to-skin care (STSC) in a rural African community and inform a behavior-based health intervention.
results_summary: The study found significant barriers to STSC, including postpartum pain and fear of harming the umbilicus, with no participants practicing it continuously. Despite challenges, STSC promotion was deemed vital for newborn survival in low-resource settings.
population_specificity: Predominantly rural, agrarian communities in Kintampo, Ghana, with diverse ethnic groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and safety of Skin-to-skin care (SSC) for pain control in neonates undergoing painful procedures, comparing it to no intervention, sucrose, or other analgesics, and examining factors like duration and provider of SSC.
results_summary: SSC was found effective for pain relief during procedures like heel lance, as measured by composite pain indicators, with no reported adverse events. Physiological indicators showed no significant differences, while behavioural indicators favoured SSC, though with potential bias.
population_specificity: Term infants (>37 weeks postmenstrual age) and preterm infants (<37 weeks postmenstrual age).
study_duration: Duration varied by study (specifics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether home visits promoting skin-to-skin care (SSC) increased its adoption, especially among low birthweight babies in rural Ghana.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased SSC adoption (19.4% higher in Newhints zones) and doubled SSC for more than 2 hours (7.5% vs. control), with greater effects for LBW babies. However, overall SSC duration remained low.
population_specificity: Live births in seven rural districts of Brong Ahafo Region, Ghana, including 10.1% low birthweight babies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate infant thermal balance and the physical environment in extremely preterm infants during skin-to-skin care (SSC).
results_summary: Infants maintained normal body temperature during SSC, though skin temperature dropped during transfer but increased during SSC. Ambient humidity and temperature were lower during SSC, and insensible water loss through the skin was higher, but the increased loss was small and did not affect fluid balance.
population_specificity: Extremely preterm infants (gestational age 22-26 weeks; postnatal age, 2-9 days).
study_duration: Measurements were taken during pretest (in incubator), test (during SSC), and posttest (in incubator) periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the experiences of healthy mothers practicing skin-to-skin care with their healthy, full-term infants in the first days after birth.
results_summary: The study found that skin-to-skin care initiated a positive spiral of mutual interaction, enhancing mother-infant affinity and promoting happiness, peace, and satisfaction in newborns, even those who were initially crying or troublesome.
population_specificity: Healthy mothers of healthy, full-term infants who had childbirth in a hospital setting.
study_duration: First days after birth (interviews conducted 1-2 weeks post-birth)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve skin-to-skin care and exclusive breastfeeding rates at hospital discharge using a quality improvement pilot study and electronic health record review.
results_summary: The study found a significant 25% improvement in skin-to-skin care rates post-intervention, particularly among cesarean section patients, but no significant change in exclusive breastfeeding rates. Babies completing all nine instinctive stages during skin-to-skin care were more likely to exclusively breastfeed.
population_specificity: Mothers and newborns in a U.S. hospital setting, including cesarean section patients.
study_duration: 5-day pilot study (Part 1); post-intervention data collected over 5 months (Part 2)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acceptability and effectiveness of skin-to-skin care (STSC) in preventing newborn hypothermia and its cultural integration in rural Uttar Pradesh, India.
results_summary: STSC was highly accepted and perceived to prevent newborn hypothermia, enhance maternal bonding, and protect against cultural beliefs. Hypothermia incidence was high, but STSC showed potential benefits without reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Rural mothers and newborns in Uttar Pradesh, India, including low birth weight (LBW) and normal birth weight (NBW) infants.
study_duration: Measurements taken on day of life 0 or 1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of early skin-to-skin contact between mothers and their healthy full-term babies on breastfeeding initiation, duration, and maternal satisfaction.
results_summary: Skin-to-skin care showed a non-significant increase in successful first breastfeeding (91% vs. 83%) and breastfeeding rates at 4 months (43% vs. 40%). Mothers in the skin-to-skin group reported higher satisfaction (90% vs. 59%) and preference for future use (86% vs. 30%), and babies had slightly higher body temperatures post-birth.
population_specificity: Healthy full-term babies and their mothers in a UK hospital setting.
study_duration: Immediate post-delivery intervention, with follow-up at 4 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the type and duration of mother-infant contact (skin-to-skin vs. wrapped holding) in preterm newborns (32-37 weeks gestation) receiving kangaroo care versus standard care.
results_summary: Skin-to-skin contact was lower than expected (22.0% postpartum, 7.5% NICU for KC dyads), but total contact time (skin-to-skin plus wrapped holding) for KC dyads was more than double that of controls. Hospital and social barriers limited skin-to-skin implementation.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (32 to <37 weeks gestation) and their mothers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of Kangaroo care (KC) for adolescent parents of preterm twins and identify different KC methods for twins.
results_summary: The study found that KC helped adolescent parents interact with, respond to, and take responsibility for their preterm twins, suggesting it was an effective intervention. Three KC methods for twins were identified: separate, sequential, and shared.
population_specificity: Adolescent parents of 32-week preterm twin sons.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility of implementing kangaroo care (skin-to-skin care) at the beginning of colicky episodes in infants.
results_summary: The study found that conducting the intervention via the internet was not feasible due to a high dropout rate (only 2 out of 75 participants completed all parts). Kangaroo care was suggested as a promising intervention, but the study lacked sufficient data to evaluate its efficacy.
population_specificity: Mothers of colicky infants.
study_duration: 2 weeks of kangaroo care intervention, followed by 2 days without it.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep hygiene education improves sleep quality and reduces fatigue in patients with OSAS (Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome) and atrial fibrillation.
results_summary: Sleep hygiene education showed no significant improvement in sleep quality subscales but reduced fatigue, concentration, motivation, and physical activity scores in the intervention group after one month. It positively affected sleep duration but was ineffective in ensuring high-quality sleep.
population_specificity: Patients with atrial fibrillation receiving inpatient treatment in a cardiology service.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a sleep hygiene training program on sleep quality in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The sleep hygiene program significantly improved global sleep quality and specific components (subjective sleep quality, sleep latency, sleep disturbances, and daytime dysfunction) in the intervention group compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore parents' perceptions of skin-to-skin care with preterm infants on assisted ventilation and identify factors influencing their decision to continue or discontinue the practice.
results_summary: The study found that parents experienced ambivalence (yearning to hold their infant but feeling apprehensive), emphasized the need for a supportive environment, and valued the special quality of parent-infant interaction. Differences in narratives highlighted the importance of individualized care, with some parents resuming skin-to-skin care at home after discontinuing it in the hospital.
population_specificity: Preterm infants on assisted ventilation and their parents (eight mothers and one father).
study_duration: Not specified beyond the two sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the delivery and effectiveness of Sleep Restriction Therapy (SRT) by primary care nurses compared to a sleep hygiene booklet alone for adults with insomnia disorder.
results_summary: SRT was successfully delivered by practice nurses and generally well-received, with improvements in sleep efficiency for participants who engaged positively, while those who struggled with adherence or had negative attitudes did not show benefits. Challenges included treatment complexity, patient difficulties maintaining SRT, and contextual barriers like nurse time constraints.
population_specificity: Adults with insomnia disorder in a general practice setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the dynamics of cumulative neurobehavioural impairment caused by chronic sleep restriction and the impact of a 1-day dose-response intervention sleep opportunity.
results_summary: The study found that neurobehavioural impairment accumulated across two 5-day periods of sleep restriction, with minimal and short-lived effects from a 1-day intervention sleep opportunity. Long-term sleep-wake history dominated subsequent neurobehavioural functioning regardless of the intervention.
population_specificity: 70 healthy adults
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction to 4 hours per day, with intervention sleep doses ranging from 0 to 12 hours
study_duration: Two 5-day periods of sleep restriction separated by a 1-day intervention

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction during abstinence from oxycodone self-administration would increase drug seeking behavior in rats.
results_summary: Sleep restriction during abstinence did not significantly affect oxycodone seeking in extinction or footshock reinstatement tests. Some behavioral phenotypes were associated with drug seeking, but these varied by sex and assessment type.
population_specificity: Male and female rats undergoing oxycodone self-administration and abstinence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise could mitigate the negative effects of sleep restriction on mood state and alertness.
results_summary: Sleep restriction significantly worsened mood, wellness, and alertness, and exercise did not mitigate these effects. Both sleep-restricted groups showed increased fatigue and slower reaction times compared to the normal sleep group.
population_specificity: 24 healthy young males
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction (TST = 230 ± 5 min or 235 ± 5 min with exercise)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical and cost-effectiveness of nurse-delivered sleep restriction therapy compared to sleep hygiene for treating insomnia disorder in primary care.
results_summary: Sleep restriction therapy significantly reduced insomnia severity at 6 months compared to sleep hygiene (mean ISI score 10.9 vs. 13.9, p<0.0001) and was likely cost-effective with an incremental cost per QALY gained of £2076. Serious adverse events were rare and unrelated to the intervention.
population_specificity: Adults with insomnia disorder (mean age 55.4, 76.2% female) recruited from general practices in England.
effective_dosage: Four sessions of nurse-delivered sleep restriction therapy plus a sleep hygiene booklet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction therapy reduces rapid eye movement (REM) sleep fragmentation compared to a control intervention in individuals with insomnia.
results_summary: The study found no significant group differences in the primary REM fragmentation index at week 1 or week 4. However, secondary indices showed small-to-medium reductions in REM fragmentation in the sleep restriction group at week 1, but not at week 4. No effects were observed for non-REM sleep fragmentation.
population_specificity: 56 participants (39 female, mean age 40.78 ± 9.08 years) with insomnia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (sleep restriction therapy vs. time in bed regularisation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate different measures of adherence to cognitive behavioural therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) involving sleep restriction and their relationship with treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that none of the adherence measures predicted insomnia severity, and baseline factors like dysfunctional thoughts, depression, or perfectionism did not predict adherence. Most patients benefited from treatment, but the small sample size and limited variance in outcomes may explain the lack of significant findings.
population_specificity: 23 patients diagnosed with insomnia according to DSM-5 criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sleep fragmentation and partial sleep restriction on cardiac autonomic tone using heart rate variability (HRV) parameters.
results_summary: Sleep restriction significantly increased heart rate and decreased HRV parameters, indicating heightened sympathetic tone and reduced vagal tone, while sleep fragmentation showed no significant effects on cardiac autonomic modulation. Recovery effects were observed for some HRV parameters after sleep restriction.
population_specificity: Twenty male subjects, aged 40.6 ± 7.5 years.
effective_dosage: 5 hours of sleep per night (sleep restriction) or awakenings every hour (sleep fragmentation).
study_duration: 2 weeks, with one intervention night per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sleep restriction therapy and sleep compression therapy on objective sleep measures, focusing on the magnitude and timing of these effects.
results_summary: Sleep restriction initially reduced total sleep time compared to sleep compression, but both treatments improved sleep continuity, with earlier improvements in sleep restriction. No substantial differences were found between the two treatments after 10 weeks.
population_specificity: 36 participants with insomnia from a larger study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of chronic sleep restriction (CSR) on the IGF-1 signaling pathway and its role in modulating amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide metabolism and cortical deposition.
results_summary: CSR decreased circulating IGF-1 levels in mice and increased Aβ accumulation in the frontal cortex, along with elevated BACE-1 and C99 expressions. Down-regulating IGF-1R reduced Aβ deposition by inhibiting BACE-1 activity, independent of body weight changes.
population_specificity: 8-week-old IGF-1R+/- and wild-type C57BL/6 mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified (CSR induced via slowly rotating drum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether armodafinil, a wakefulness promoter, could enhance the effectiveness of sleep restriction therapy (SRT) for insomnia disorder by mitigating its daytime side effects.
results_summary: SRT alone showed a robust clinical response in reducing insomnia severity, but adding armodafinil did not provide additional benefits and was statistically inferior to historical controls. The combination was associated with frequent minor side effects but was generally safe and acceptable.
population_specificity: Insomnia patients (25 in the trial, 33 historical controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how sleep restriction affects skeletal muscle transcriptome related to glucose metabolism and whether exercise could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: Sleep restriction increased inflammatory and immune response pathways in skeletal muscle, while exercise attenuated these changes. No significant individual gene-level changes were observed, but exercise reversed some transcriptional alterations seen with sleep deprivation.
population_specificity: 20 healthy young males
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction (4 hours time in bed per night) with or without three high-intensity interval exercise sessions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how chronic sleep restriction affects the circadian rhythm of clock genes and downstream output signals in mice.
results_summary: Sleep restriction disrupted the circadian rhythm of clock genes (e.g., Cry1, Per1/2/3) and altered the acrophase of others (e.g., Bmal1, Clock). It also affected upstream signals (ERK, EIFs) and downstream plasma output signals (melatonin, corticosterone, IL-6, TNF-α), indicating circadian dysfunction.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of short-term sleep restriction followed by recovery on subjective health status, inflammation, and lipid metabolism in individuals with and without cold hypersensitivity (CH).
results_summary: Short-term sleep restriction led to increased stress, impaired quality of life (QOL), and decreased LDL-C levels, with more pronounced effects in the CH group. The study suggests that CH status may influence clinical risks associated with insufficient sleep.
population_specificity: 118 healthy adults aged 35-44 years without pre-existing sleep disturbances.
effective_dosage: 4-hour sleep restriction per day for 3 days.
study_duration: 3 days of sleep restriction followed by 4 days of recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and mechanisms of sleep restriction therapies (sleep restriction therapy and bedtime restriction therapy) as standalone interventions for chronic insomnia in middle childhood, including effects on anxiety, cognitive performance, and parasomnias.
results_summary: Both sleep restriction groups showed significant reductions in total sleep time and increases in evening sleepiness during treatment, with maintained improvements in insomnia at follow-up. Anxiety and worry improved across all groups, but no differences were found between restriction and control groups; no adverse effects on cognitive functioning or parasomnias were observed.
population_specificity: 61 children aged 6-14 years (mean 9.1 years, 54% female) with chronic insomnia disorder.
effective_dosage: Two weekly 60-minute treatment sessions with a psychologist.
study_duration: 2-week treatment period with follow-up at 4 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplemental protein and multinutrient supplementation improved wound healing markers after acute stress induced by 72-hour sleep restriction.
results_summary: The study found that skin barrier restoration was significantly faster with the multinutrient supplement (NUT) compared to placebo (PLA). However, no treatment effects were observed on cytokine levels from wound fluid.
population_specificity: Generally healthy young adults (18 males, 2 females; mean age 19.7 ± 2.30 years).
effective_dosage: 1.50 g · kg-1 · d-1 protein plus multinutrient beverage (l-arginine: 20.0 g/d; l-glutamine: 30.0 g/d; omega-3 fatty acids: 1.00 g/d; zinc sulfate: 24.0 mg/d; cholecalciferol: 800 IU/d; vitamin C: 400 mg/d).
study_duration: During 72-hour sleep restriction and for 4 days afterward.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of chronic sleep restriction (CSR) on sleep continuity and structure in healthy individuals with satiated sleep needs, as well as its effects on neurobehavioral performance.
results_summary: CSR reduced sleep duration by ~95 minutes per night, increased Slow-Wave Activity, and consolidated sleep, but sustained vigilant attention did not fully recover even after nine nights of recovery. Traditional sleep quality metrics improved, but neurobehavioral performance deteriorated.
population_specificity: Nine healthy participants with satiated sleep needs.
study_duration: 21 nights of CSR, preceded by 4 nights of sleep extension and followed by 9 nights of recovery sleep.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of sulforaphane and other bioactive dietary compounds on human breast cancer cell lines and explore their potential therapeutic mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that sulforaphane modulates epigenetic mechanisms such as DNA methylation and histone modifications, potentially reversing molecular alterations in cancer cells. These effects suggest therapeutic potential for breast cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer cell lines (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the cardioprotective potential of sulforaphane and other phytochemicals by modulating sirtuin-mediated deacetylation in cardiovascular diseases.
results_summary: The study suggests sulforaphane has cardioprotective effects, likely through modulation of protein acetylation levels, similar to other sirtuin activators and phytochemicals. However, specific results for sulforaphane are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cardiovascular disease context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the role of HDAC6 in physiological and cancerous conditions and explore the anticancer properties of natural-derived compounds, including Sulforaphane, through HDAC6 modulation.
results_summary: The abstract highlights HDAC6 as a potential therapeutic target in cancer and mentions the anticancer properties of natural-derived compounds, including Sulforaphane, via HDAC6-related pathways, but does not provide specific results for Sulforaphane.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of HDAC6 in cancer and physiological conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the modulation of the Nrf2 pathway by natural compounds, including Sulforaphane, and its implications for anticancer strategies.
results_summary: The study found that Sulforaphane and other natural compounds can modulate the Nrf2 pathway, which may have anticancer effects, but Nrf2 activation in cancer cells could also lead to chemoresistance. The role of Nrf2 in cancer depends on tight control of its activity, tumor microenvironment, and cell type.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of Nrf2 modulation in cancer)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Sulforaphane, among other phytochemicals, as a chemopreventive agent and adjuvant therapy for Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma (HNSCC).
results_summary: Sulforaphane was found to inhibit HNSCC growth by regulating cancer cell proliferation, impeding cell cycle progression, inducing apoptosis, and preventing angiogenesis. It also showed potential to protect normal cells during treatment and reduce damage from chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients at risk for or with developed Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma (HNSCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the epigenetic modifications in melanoma and the potential role of bioactive phytochemicals, including Sulforaphane, in modulating these changes for skin cancer prevention and therapy.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that bioactive phytochemicals, such as Sulforaphane, exhibit epigenetic modulatory capabilities, which may influence genes involved in cell cycle, proliferation, motility, and apoptosis, suggesting potential chemopreventive and therapeutic effects against skin cancer.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on melanoma and nonmelanoma skin cancers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the neuroprotective effects of sulforaphane (SFN) and its metabolite erucin (ERN) against oxidative stress in Parkinson's disease models.
results_summary: SFN showed superior neuroprotective effects compared to ERN in vitro, increasing Nrf2 protein, mRNA Nrf2, and total GSH levels, while both compounds exhibited similar effects when administered simultaneously with oxidative stress. These findings were confirmed in a mouse model of Parkinson's disease.
population_specificity: SH-SY5Y cells (in vitro) and a 6-OHDA-PD mouse model (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high glucosinolate diet (leading to sulforaphane production) could influence osteoarthritis progression by analyzing synovial fluid and plasma biomarkers in knee osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: The high glucosinolate diet resulted in detectable ITCs (including sulforaphane) in synovial fluid and plasma, with 125 differentially expressed proteins in synovial fluid, suggesting a biological effect. The study sets the stage for further clinical trials to assess functional outcomes.
population_specificity: 40 patients with knee osteoarthritis undergoing total knee replacement.
effective_dosage: Not specified (high vs. low glucosinolate diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, bioavailability, and efficacy of sulforaphane as a chemopreventive agent for bladder cancer.
results_summary: Sulforaphane was found to be bioavailable both systemically and in the bladder, potent in inhibiting bladder cancer carcinogenesis through multiple mechanisms, and safe at the studied doses without toxicities. Epidemiological, in vitro, preclinical, and early-phase trial data support its potential as a chemopreventive agent.
population_specificity: Patients at risk for or with bladder cancer (early and late stages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Sulforaphane's potential as an EZH2 inhibitor and its anti-cancer effects among other natural products.
results_summary: Sulforaphane was identified as an EZH2 modulator, potentially suppressing cancer through mechanisms like histone methylation inhibition and down-regulation of matrix metalloproteinase expression. The abstract suggests Sulforaphane may offer anti-cancer benefits with low cytotoxic effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cancer-related mechanisms discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current understanding of pancreatic cancer stem cells (CSCs) and evaluate natural compounds, including sulforaphane, for their potential to target these cells.
results_summary: The abstract suggests sulforaphane is among the phytochemicals that may inhibit pancreatic CSCs, potentially offering a novel approach for prevention and treatment, though specific results for sulforaphane are not detailed.
population_specificity: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (theoretical or preclinical focus, not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the metabolic fate, biological effects, and potential health benefits of glucosinolate breakdown products, particularly sulforaphane, with a focus on anti-cancer effects and other diseases.
results_summary: Epidemiological and clinical evidence suggests sulforaphane has potential anti-cancer effects, supported by multiple molecular mechanisms such as modulation of inflammation, apoptosis, and epigenetic regulation. Ongoing clinical trials may further clarify its protective effects against cancer and other diseases.
population_specificity: General human population, with emphasis on epidemiological and clinical trial data.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential chemopreventive and therapeutic effects of sulforaphane against cancer, focusing on its mechanisms and clinical relevance.
results_summary: Sulforaphane demonstrated multi-level anticancer activity, including DNA damage protection, cell cycle modulation, pro-apoptotic, anti-angiogenesis, and anti-metastasis effects, primarily via Nrf2 activation. Clinical data are limited but suggest promise as an adjuvant therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of experimental and clinical data)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential therapeutic utility of sulforaphane in alleviating neuroinflammation and neurodegeneration associated with Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study suggests sulforaphane may modulate neuroinflammation by targeting the NLRP3 inflammasome, potentially offering neuroprotective effects against Alzheimer's disease symptoms. However, specific clinical outcomes or direct efficacy data were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on Alzheimer's disease and neuroinflammation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss experimental evidence pointing to mitochondrial dysfunction in cancer chemoprevention by promising phytochemicals, including sulforaphane.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that sulforaphane and other phytochemicals target mitochondria to induce cancer cell-selective death, suggesting potential efficacy in cancer chemoprevention. However, specific results on sulforaphane's effects are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Preclinical models (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of sulforaphane as a therapeutic intervention for autism spectrum disorders (ASD) by modulating cellular stress responses and heat shock protein expression.
results_summary: The study suggests sulforaphane may improve cognition and behavior in ASD by inducing metabolic effects similar to those seen during febrile illness, potentially offering neuroprotective benefits. However, the findings require cautious interpretation and further research.
population_specificity: Children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the potential of sulforaphane and other phytochemicals as therapeutic agents targeting breast cancer stem cells (CSCs) to control recurrence and metastasis.
results_summary: The abstract suggests sulforaphane may target breast CSCs and their signaling pathways, potentially serving as a novel therapeutic agent for breast cancer treatment and future drug development.
population_specificity: Breast cancer (specifically focusing on cancer stem cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate sulforaphane's effects on AGE formation and RAGE-mediated signaling pathways in various cell types and organs, including endothelial cells, vessels, and heart.
results_summary: The study suggests sulforaphane may block the AGE-RAGE axis, potentially reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and fibrosis, which could protect against cardiovascular disease. However, specific results for sulforaphane are summarized alongside other phytochemicals without detailed standalone data.
population_specificity: Various cell types and organs (endothelial cells, vessels, heart); no specific human population mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sulforaphane supplementation could induce antioxidant gene expression and protect against neutrophilic airway inflammation in healthy humans exposed to ozone.
results_summary: The study found that sulforaphane supplementation did not induce antioxidant gene expression or protect against neutrophilic airway inflammation in the ozone-exposure model, suggesting it is not a promising candidate for larger clinical trials targeting airway inflammation.
population_specificity: Healthy human subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the potential of sulforaphane, among other phytochemicals, in preventing colorectal cancer by exploring its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study suggests sulforaphane exhibits strong antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-cancer effects by modulating specific signaling pathways and molecular markers, potentially inhibiting colorectal cancer development. However, clinical validation is needed to confirm these preventive effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies referenced, but no human population detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Sulforaphane (SFN) as a potential HDAC inhibitor for treating pancreatic cancer and explore its molecular mechanisms and combinatorial therapeutic strategies.
results_summary: The study found that SFN exhibits cytotoxic effects in pancreatic cancer models by modulating histone and nonhistone proteins, inducing cell cycle arrest, differentiation, and apoptosis. It also highlights SFN's potential in combination therapies to overcome chemoresistance and reduce toxicity.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer models (in vitro or in vivo, not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the chemopreventive potential of sulforaphane against carcinogen-induced oral cancer using in vitro and in vivo models, and to assess its bioavailability and pharmacodynamic activity in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: Sulforaphane induced NRF2 and its target genes, reduced pSTAT3 activity, and significantly decreased tumor incidence and size in mice. In humans, sulforaphane-rich broccoli sprout extract showed the greatest bioavailability, and mucosal bioactivity was observed in a subset of participants.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers (10 participants) and murine models of oral cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the chemopreventive potential of sulforaphane on liver carcinogenesis through epigenetic mechanisms.
results_summary: The study suggests sulforaphane may reduce the occurrence or delay the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) by modifying deregulated epigenetic mechanisms, based on in vitro and in vivo models.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo models of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Sulforaphane's potential role in prostate cancer therapy, focusing on its molecular mechanisms and therapeutic strategies for resistant cases.
results_summary: Sulforaphane, as an HDAC inhibitor, shows promise in prostate cancer therapy by inducing cell growth arrest, differentiation, and apoptosis. Combined therapy enhances its efficacy, though its standalone effects are limited.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer (no specific patient demographics provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if topical broccoli sprout extract (BSE), enriched for sulforaphane, could induce the expression of homologous keratins (K6, K17, K16) in human epidermis without affecting defective keratins (K5/K14) for potential therapeutic use in epidermolysis bullosa simplex.
results_summary: Topical BSE activated nuclear factor (erythroid-derived 2)-like 2 and upregulated K17 in all subjects, had variable effects on K16 and K6, and did not alter K14 or K5 expression. The study concluded BSE is a promising therapeutic candidate for K14-associated epidermolysis bullosa simplex.
population_specificity: Five subjects (34-71 years old), with one excluded due to poor tissue quality.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore sulforaphane's potential as a therapeutic agent for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) by targeting several physiological pathways associated with ASD.
results_summary: The study suggests sulforaphane may regulate key ASD-related pathways, including oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, immune dysregulation, heat shock response, and synaptic dysfunction, with potential to improve core and associated ASD symptoms. Biomarkers were identified to assess these pathways and guide treatment strategies.
population_specificity: Children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if ingestion of broccoli sprouts (a rich source of sulforaphane) improves airway inflammation, oxidative stress, and asthma symptoms in atopic adults with asthma.
results_summary: Despite increasing serum sulforaphane levels, 3-day broccoli sprout ingestion did not reduce airway inflammation (FENO), oxidative stress markers, or improve lung function or asthma symptoms. No significant changes in cytoprotective gene expression or inflammatory biomarkers were observed.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-50 with asthma and allergic sensitization to an indoor allergen.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if sulforaphane (SFN) could safely activate NRF2 to restore oxidative capacity and increase fetal hemoglobin in sickle cell disease (SCD) patients.
results_summary: BSH containing SFN was well tolerated, increased HMOX1 mRNA levels significantly, and showed a trend toward increased HBG1 mRNA levels, but no significant changes in HbF protein were observed.
population_specificity: Adults with stable sickle cell disease (SCD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Sulforaphane's potential as a chemoprevention agent against various cancers and other diseases, focusing on its mechanisms and clinical applications.
results_summary: Sulforaphane demonstrated broad-spectrum efficacy in preclinical models against multiple cancers, cardiovascular disease, neurodegenerative diseases, and diabetes, primarily through activation of the Nrf2-Keap1 pathway. Clinical studies utilized broccoli sprout preparations rich in Sulforaphane or its precursor, showing promising pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic profiles.
population_specificity: Preclinical models and clinical studies (specific human populations not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare sulforaphane's ability to activate Nrf2 and induce cytoprotective genes with other phytochemicals, assessing its potential clinical efficacy as a complementary medicine.
results_summary: Sulforaphane was found to more potently activate Nrf2 and induce cytoprotective genes compared to other phytochemicals like curcumin, silymarin, and resveratrol, due to its high bioavailability and lipophilic nature. It favorably modified genes associated with chemoprevention, highlighting its therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of phytochemical effects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the role of natural products, including sulforaphane, in cancer chemoprevention and therapy.
results_summary: The abstract emphasizes sulforaphane as a dietary phytochemical with potential chemopreventive properties, alongside other natural products, but does not provide specific study results on its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of sulforaphane, among other phytochemicals, in targeting cancer and cancer stem cells (CSCs) by interfering with self-renewal pathways and molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The abstract suggests sulforaphane has anti-proliferative, anti-metastatic, ROS-inducing, anti-angiogenic, and pro-apoptotic effects, with efficacy in targeting CSCs and malignancy-related pathways. However, specific results for sulforaphane alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on cancer and CSCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anti-cancer activities of sulforaphane and other phytochemical-derived compounds, focusing on their cytotoxicity against tumors and potential combination strategies with other drugs.
results_summary: The abstract highlights sulforaphane as a bioactive marker for cytotoxicity against tumors but does not provide specific results on its efficacy or mechanisms. It emphasizes the need for further elucidation of its anti-cancer effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Sulforaphane, via the Nrf2/ARE pathway, to protect mitochondrial function and mitigate oxidative stress in neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: Sulforaphane demonstrated promising protection of mitochondrial function in models of oxidative stress and neurodegenerative diseases, suggesting its potential as a preventive and therapeutic agent for aging-associated neurodegenerative conditions.
population_specificity: Models of oxidative stress and neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Huntington's, ALS).
